qas.question: What dish is commonly considered to be penultimate culinary achievement in New Haven?
What is the colloquial term afforded to New Haven-style pizza?
At what New Haven establishment did "apizza" make it's inaugural appearance in 1925?
What ingredient is notably absent from a New Haven-style pizza when ordered plain?
In what section of New Haven would one expect to find an outstanding white clam pie pizza on Wooster Street?
New Haven, in terms of food is best known for what?
Where did New Haven pizza style originated from?
In general what are "apizza" known for?
White clam pie is found in what district of New Haven?

answers.text: Wooster Street in the Little Italy section

qas.question: In what year was New Haven-style pizza found?

context: New Haven's greatest culinary claim to fame may be its <a5_0>pizza<a5_0/>, which has been claimed to be among the best in the country, or even in the world. <a0_0>New Haven-style pizza<a0_0/>, called <a1_0>"apizza"<a1_0/> (pronounced ah-BEETS, [aˈpitts] in the original Italian dialect), made its debut at the iconic <a2_0><a6_0>Frank Pepe Pizzeria Napoletana<a6_0/><a2_0/> (known as Pepe's) in <a9_0>1925<a9_0/>. Apizza is baked in coal- or wood-fired brick ovens, and is notable for <a7_0>its thin crust<a7_0/>. Apizza may be red (with a tomato-based sauce) or white (with a sauce of garlic and olive oil), and pies ordered "plain" are made without the otherwise customary <a3_0>mozzarella cheese<a3_0/> (originally smoked mozzarella, known as "scamorza" in Italian). A white clam pie is a well-known specialty of the restaurants on <a8_0>Wooster Street in the <a4_0>Little Italy<a4_0/> section<a8_0/> of New Haven, including Pepe's and Sally's Apizza (which opened in 1938). Modern Apizza on State Street, which opened in 1934, is also well-known.
